title: Blog
text:
From reading How to be a Modern Scientist by Jeff Leek, I have learned tips on the practice of being a good scientist that are often not taught explicitly in academic courses, but are often left up to individuals pursuing in academic career to figure out in bits and pieces on their own. The book discussed several topics that were helpful, ranging from best practices for writing a manuscript to career planning in academia. One of the most helpful parts of the book was the section explaining the process of peer review of manuscripts by journals. Even after having been a first author on scientific papers in the past, wherein I had to field reviewers’ comments and quesitons about my work, I didn’t truly understand the standards that most reviewers abide by until I read this book. My key takeaways, both from the perspective of having my manuscript be reviewed and being a future peer reviewer, were the following:

You should never take more than a month to review (which gave me some justification at being annoyed with reviewers who take ages to return a time-sensitive manuscript).
Don’t be a “jerk reviewer”. In other words, don’t ask for revisions and waste the authors’ time if you wouldn’t accept the manuscript even if they made the changes requested.
It is totally valid to get credit for peer reviewing papers (through platforms such as Publons). This makes sense to me because performing a good review takes lots of time and effort and receiving credit for this work would incentivize more scientists to be reviewers.

The book also strongly recommended creating an online presence and identity to promote one’s career. This idea was, and still is, quite daunting to me. The internet is a scary place and I would generally like to stay far away from the vitriolic arguments that can place on social media over controversial scientific findings. However, I would like to lean into the new age of scientific discourse, much of which now happens online and in public forums. I do have a twitter account already and will try to at least be more active in following journals that publicize their newly published articles and promote the articles I’m most excited about.

title: Biography
text:
Biography
I am an M4 at the Cleveland Clinic Lerner College of Medicine (CCLCM), an MD program with a particular emphasis on training physician-scientists. I am interested in pursuing ophthalmology, which a particular interest in the ocular manifestations of neurodegeneration, such as optic neuritis and glaucoma. I am fascinated by research questions in both the basic science/translational and clinical research realms and have been involved in a broad spectrum of projects throughout my training.
I am also passionate about using my platform and resources as a medical student to address the health disparities in the Greater Cleveland area. As the Student Lead of the Service Learning & Community Outreach action group at CCLCM, I helped start a student-run health clinic at the Haven Home, a temporary housing shelter for women and children experiencing homelessness, as well as a comprehensive health curriculum for students grades 6-8 at a local elementary school. Both projects have continued to flourish and expand over the past two years!
In my spare time, I enjoy traveling to national parks, singing, and exploring food spots around Cleveland!


Education
Doctor of Medicine (MD), 2020 - Present | Cleveland Clinic Lerner College of Medicine
Master in Public Health (MPH), 2020 - 2024  | Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine
Bachelor of Science (BS), 2014 - 2018 | University of Washington

title: Photography
text:
As a wizard and scholar of Middle-earth, I have been studying the magic of the natural world for centuries. Through my self-portraits, I aim to capture the essence of my own being and reflect on my own journey through time. Each photograph is a reflection of my own experiences and emotions. Through my photography, I hope to offer a glimpse into my life as a scholar and adventurer, and inspire others to reflect on their own journeys through the world.
